headline: Opinion | The Christian Right Is Dead. The Religious Right Killed It. - The New York Times
context: You’re reading the David French newsletter, for Times subscribers only.  Reflections on law and culture, war and peace, and the deeper trends that define and divide America.

annotations.paragraph: There have been two competing narratives about the rise of the Christian right in the United States.
annotations.reason: Introduces the main topic of the article by mentioning the competing narratives.

annotations.paragraph: The first story is the one we conservative evangelicals told ourselves: Religious conservatism arose as a force in the United States in response to the hedonism of the sexual revolution, the cultural intolerance of the New Left and the threat of the Soviet Union, an explicitly atheistic, Marxist empire.
annotations.reason: Provides context and background on one of the narratives about the rise of the Christian right.

annotations.paragraph: According to this narrative, the Supreme Court’s decision in Roe v. Wade in 1973 was the seminal domestic event of Christian conservatism. It represented a deadly corruption of our Constitution in service of a culture of sexual convenience in which human life was subordinate to sexual pleasure.
annotations.reason: Offers specific historical context related to the narrative of Christian conservatism's rise.
